@ijuma @hachikuji This enables the request logger (and a few others, both uncommented and commented in the default `log4j.properties`) and directed at `NullAppender`. This exercises the code around them, especially the request logger all the way at `TRACE` level, but doesn't affect any output.

This causes tests to correctly fail if something is wrong with the logging. In the unit tests, `kafka.network.SocketServerTest.testGracefulClose` fails because it expects a response. In the integration tests, a ton of things fail.

This definitely isn't perfect since redirecting to a `NullAppender` kind of hides the cause, but at least it doesn't let bad commits through. This isn't ideal, but at least people familiar with the issue will be able to track the issue down. (We could also add a note to the unit test about modifying the loggers if we think that would be useful in debugging future issues.)

I can't tell precisely what log4j considers public API, but this `NullAppender` has been around for a long time with a total of 2 commits, so seems reliable. Still, if people aren't sure about it, we can pull a copy into the tests given that it's a trivial nop implementation anyway.
@ijuma @dguy This cuts the aggregate test time for core's unit tests in half because one test derived from this class takes about 2.5 minutes.

@ijuma Can you take a look (and merge if it is ok), please? Thank you!

This is a fix for the failure in https://builds.apache.org/job/kafka-pr-jdk8-scala2.12/5268/
```
java.util.ConcurrentModificationException: KafkaConsumer is not safe for multi-threaded access
	at org.apache.kafka.clients.consumer.KafkaConsumer.acquire(KafkaConsumer.java:1638)
	at org.apache.kafka.clients.consumer.KafkaConsumer.close(KafkaConsumer.java:1536)
	at org.apache.kafka.clients.consumer.KafkaConsumer.close(KafkaConsumer.java:1514)
	at kafka.api.IntegrationTestHarness.$anonfun$tearDown$2(IntegrationTestHarness.scala:99)
	at kafka.api.IntegrationTestHarness.$anonfun$tearDown$2$adapted(IntegrationTestHarness.scala:99)
```

Nope, still a problem, seems the tests get skipped with the annotation. Just did this as a side effect of noticing how slow the unit tests were...

Search doesn't seem to be showing up a corresponding JIRA to follow up on. Do we plan to follow up and is JUnit 4.13 likely to get released? Seems like it's been *quite* awhile since 4.12. Don't want to bother with follow up if it'll never be released.

However, there's a subjective element to some of the changes and
would be great to get some feedback. Each change is in a separate
commit. This PR includes https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/3316. I will rebase once that's merged.

I think the restore callbacks etc look good. My main question will be around the bulk loading part, i.e., if we go with batch loading, will we still be able to look into KAFKA-4868 or are they mutually exclusive? Thanks @bbejeck .
LGTM. Really nice work, @ijuma.
For Streams, it would be an error. We use unique IDs for all clients -- a naming conflict would prohibit correct metric reports and should never happen.
Retest this please.
Failing system test was due to broker bug that got fixed. Rebased and rerunning system test now: https://jenkins.confluent.io/job/system-test-kafka-branch-builder-2/326/

@enothereska  current plan is to have KAFKA-4868 be part of the bulk/batch loading in this PR
LGTM. Merged to trunk and 0.11.0.

> Is this really an error? Would this happen if there are multiple apps in the same process?

I think a more general question is that, would we require a different app info for different client / broker-id. If we assume broker-id / client-id should be unique, then such error should never happen since otherwise some clients will not be able to register this app information.
LGTM. Merged to 0.10.2.
@guozhangwang I'd like to rebase this PR and run one more time for clarification.
TC side logging changes LGTM. Producer's side changes also look reasonable, but I may not be the perfect person to decide.
